 1. DISEASE PREVENTION IN CIUNA A. Population, Health and Nutrition Status 1.1 Population Status. China's population is estimated to have reached 1.2 billion in February 1995. Family planning efforts, starting from the early 1970s, have resulted in a decline in the total fertility rate to about 2.0 per woman in the early 1990s. In 1990, China's crude birth rate was estimated at 1.8 percent and death rate at 0.6 percent, resulting in an annual rate of natural increase of 1.2 percent. The current population has a high proportion of younger adults. Rapid economic growth during the 1980s has benefitted most of the population. Yet, nearly 100 million people (8.6 percent) were in absolute poverty in 1990, and the Government has instituted special programs for their benefit. 1.2 Health Status. Since 1949, China's achievements in health have been remarkable, and by the 1980s it had reached mortality levels comparable to middle-income countries. The 1995 World Development Report (WDR) indicates that, in 1993, China's average life expectancy at birth was 69 years, compared to 62 years for low-income countries, and the infant mortality rate (IMR) was 30 per 1,000 live births compared to 64 for low-income countries. A young and healthy adult population gives China an overall burden of disease that is less than that found anywhere outside the established market economies and the former socialist economies of Europe. 1.3 China's successes in disease prevention are based on successes in improving educational standards, in lifting most of the population out of absolute poverty and in creating a comprehensive "three-levels" network of health services covering all counties. The network consists of a general hospital, an epidemic prevention station (EPS) and a maternal and child health (MCH) station at the county level, a small hospital (average 15 beds) at the township level, and rural (formerly, "barefoot") doctors and other health workers at the village level responsible for basic curative and preventive services. By the 1970s, the three level system covered most of China, making at least limited health care accessible to nearly everyone. 1.4 Specific health education and disease prevention programs were able to build on the political and health systems established in China. Epidemic and endemic diseases, such as plague, cholera, malaria, smallpox and schistosomiasis, which were uncontrolled in the first half of this century, were reduced to very low levels or even eradicated. Other infectious diseases, such as common childhood respiratory and diarrheal illnesses and adult tuberculosis, while still important public health problems, have been greatly reduced. 1.5 Nutritional Status. Average food consumption in China compares well with other developing countries. The National Nutrition Survey of 1982 indicated that the average energy intake per capita was 2,085 calories (102 percent of recommended daily allowance or RDA) including 67 grams of protein (92 percent of RDA). Since then, rural reforms and enormous increases in agricultural production have markedly improved food intake on a broad scale. Significant micronutrient problems of China have included iodine, vitamin A and iron deficiencies. Considering that about one third of the population lives in iodine deficient areas, the Government has embarked on universal iodization of salt, which will be significantly helped by the Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Project approved in June 1995 (Cr. 2756-CHA; Ln. 3914-CHA). Vitamin A deficiency is a relatively less prevalent problem with seasonal deficiency in some areas and control measures are in
 - 2 - an experimental stage. Iron deficiency anemia remains widespread in children and women, and many experimental as well as large scale efforts have been launched to address this problem. B. Vaccine-Preventable Diseases 1.6 Strengths. Emphasis on preventive care, particularly immunizations against childhood diseases, has been a key factor in China's success in the health care of its population. In 1981, China joined the World Health Organization (WHO)-coordinated Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) against tuberculosis, diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, polio and measles. The Government provided political and financial support for immunization services at every leve] and started major efforts to expand coverage. During the 1980s, the Government as well as international organizations also made large investments in the transport and refrigeration facilities with the objective of establishing a "cold chain" for vaccines, allowing for at least six vaccination sessions per year even in poor rural areas. Consequently, coverage of the four basic vaccines1' reached 80 percent in each province by 1988, and it reached 80 percent in nearly all counties by 1990 (with an average county level of 95 percent). These achievements resulted in dramnatic reduction in the incidence of major diseases; for example, between 1978 and 1993, for every 100,000 population, pertussis decreased from 126 to 1, diphtheria from 2 to 0.01 and measles from 250 to 10. As a result of special campaigns, polio cases have been reduced by two-thirds in the period 1992-1994. The Government has now added new vaccines to the immunization program and set the targets to: (a) eradicate polio and to reduce neonatal tetanus to one per 1,000 live births by 1995; and (b) immunize 80 percent of infants against hepatitis B in urban areas, and expand coverage in rural areas. 1.7 Weaknesses. In spite of the past remarkable achievements, China's disease prevention programs, especially the immunization program, now face several stubborn problems and challenges. First, the immunization program has been an unintentional victim of China's recent economic reforms with declines in resources available for preventive care since the mid-1980s. While the overall economy and the total expenditures on health have been growing rapidly, the real per capita Government expenditures on health have stagnated and even declined, from 4.9 RMB per capita in 1982 and 6.6 RMB in 1986 to 5.9 RMB in 1993. As a result, the condition of immunization infrastructure, especially the vital cold chain, remains poor and most systems are in need of replacement. Similarly, operating budgets for the program are inadequate, causing serious shortages of syringes, needles and sterilization equipment, particularly in poorer provinces. Second, there is a wide discrepancy in coverage and quality of inmmunization programs between the poorer and richer provinces and between urban and rural areas, as shown in Table 1.1 below. In many poor areas, major system breakdowns occurred in 1993 and 1994, as many counties could not meet the minimum number of yearly immunization rounds, resulting in inadequate protection for many children. 1' Includes: BCG (baccille Calmette-Guerin, against tuberculosis), DPT (against diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus), polio and measles.

The payments to health workers based on work-points are now abolished, so that they have to rely on curative services for much of their income; this has reduced incentives to provide preventive care. In some areas the immunization services are paid for by the provinces or local communities, but most areas charge user fees either for each immunization or through a local contract system. There is an urgent need to establish a viable and affordable system to finance immunization. In particular, there is a need to establish a system to finance expensive new vaccines like hepatitis B, particularly important for China because about 10 percent of the population are carriers. Fourth, the immunization workers lack sufficient technical and management skills. Training has become even more important because of the departure of a large number of experienced health workers to pursue private practice or leave the profession altogether. Fifth, immunization coverage data are not reliable, and the system needs improvement so that better quality data can be obtained for management decisions. Finally, there is a lack of health education for families to increase their demand for essential immunization. C. Non-Communicable Diseases, Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV 1.9 Health Transition. With increasing life expectancy, a declining overall rate of death and of illness caused by infectious diseases, and a rapidly growing economy, China is experiencing a dramatic health transition. The proportion of older persons has been increasing fast and steadily: 12 percent of the population will reach age 60 or over by 2010 and 20 percent by 2030. In Shanghai, over 35 percent of the population is already over 40 years old and 14 percent over 60 years; in Beijing and Tianjin, the proportions are 30 percent and 10 percent, respectively. Consequently, disease patterns have also undergone dramatic changes, and non-communicable diseases (NCDs) already account for over three-quarters of all deaths in China. The World Bank's last health sector report!' indicated that the annual probability of death from infectious disease for adult men and women in China (ages 15 to 60) was just over one percent. In contrast, the death rate from chronic 2' China: Long-Tenn Issues and Options in the Health Transition (No. 7965-CHA), 1990.

Smoking, hypertension, poor diet, overweight and obesity and pollution are now the most important health risk factors in modern China. Over 70 percent of men and 7 percent of women smoke, making China the world's largest consumer of cigarettes. The consumption of cigarettes is growing, especially among women. The prevalence of hypertension is also increasing: from 5.11 percent (or 30 million people) in 1959, to 7.73 percent (60 million) in 1979 and to 11.88 percent (90 million) in 1991. The rate is over 20 percent in some urban areas. Over 10 percent of the Chinese population carry the hepatitis B virus, which is a major cause of liver failure and cancer. China's environmental pollution is very high, contributing to a chronic obstructive lung disease rate that is among the highest in the world. Industrial pollution, accidents and work-related injuries are also high and rising. Finally, China's increased economic and social openness have contributed to a very dramatic rise in sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) with associated risk of transmission of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). 1.11 Non-Communicable Diseases. According to recent reports (1990, 1991 and 1992) of the National Disease Surveillance Points (DSPs), NCDs accounted for 79.8 percent of deaths, and in one urban area for 89.4 percent. The most important causes were heart diseases, stroke, lung diseases, and cancer. The death rate from stroke and hypertension (mainly heart diseases) was 150/100,000 and rates of increase were 5 percent and 8.7 percent, respectively. The cancer death rate was 83.74/100,000, mainly of stomach, liver and lung. The death rate of lung cancer increased by 4.5 percent per year. The incidence of these diseases is expected to continue to increase dramatically in the absence of effective prevention measures. 1.12 Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HlV/AIDS. The population's increased mobility, economic freedoms and changing behavior have been accompanied by a resurgence in a variety of STDs and in increased HIV. Though still relatively very low in prevalence, the numbers of STDs/HIV cases have been increasing fast each year, with a real potential for explosive growth. While there is a lack of reliable data on STDs, the STD cases are believed to have risen from 2 reported cases in 1979 to a cumulative total of over 1.13 million in 1994. The main STDs are gonorrhea, syphilis and pointed wart; the adjusted rate for gonorrhea is estimated at 41 per 100,000 population. The first HIV positive case in China was reported in 1985 and, as of June 1994, over 1,600 HIV cases have been reported, including nearly 40 cases of Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). 1.13 Government Policies and Programs on NCDs, STDs and lIV. The Government is fully alert to the challenges and potential threats posed by NCDs, STDs and HIV. On NCDs, the Government has prepared a National Outline of NCD Control outlining its strategies based on multi- sectoral involvement and primary prevention. The main approaches are to include community-based prevention, training of general practitioners and improvements in primary health care. Concerning STDs and HIV, the Government emphasizes preventive measures with four main strategies: (a) information and education to promote safe sex and other healthy behavior and to discourage intravenous drug abuse; (b) effective STD case management regimes to control the spread of STDs/HIV; (c) screening of blood donations; and (d) promotion of condom use. A large number of small experiments and pilot programs have been taken up by the Government itself and with external cooperation. Many of these programs are directed toward high-risk groups and areas.
 D. Bank Group Assistance Strategy and Project Rationale 1.14 The Bank Group's Country and Sector Strategies. The project proposed by the Government is in line with China's "8-7 Plan", which aims to eliminate extreme poverty by the year 2000 and to narrow the widening health gap between the poorer rural and richer urban areas of China (see para. 2.7 for the selection of project areas). The project is also in line with the Bank Group's country and sector strategy. The Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy for China (Report No. 14454, May 1995) is to help China meet its two major challenges: (a) achieving macroeconomic stability while maintaining rapid (and more efficient) growth; and (b) sustaining this growth by shifting resources toward priority areas, including poverty reduction, human resource development, infrastructure, and environmental protection, that are currently under-funded. For the health sector, Bank assistance will focus on helping the Government: (a) to meet the basic health needs among the rural population, particularly those living in absolute poverty; and (b) to reinvigorate initiatives in disease prevention, by retaining the gains made against infectious and endemic diseases and by implementing innovative programs against non-communicable and chronic disease. The proposed project seeks to prevent vaccine-preventable diseases in ten of the poorest provinces of China and to lay a base for effective, sustainable and replicable programs against non-communicable and chronic diseases. 1.15 Rationale for IDA Involvement in the Project. IDA support for the proposed project is justified by the project's close alignment with the Bank Group strategies for its country and health sector assistance. In addition, as a result of our involvement, provincial resource allocations for immunization will improve substantially, reversing the recent declining trend in financing disease prevention. Finally, the Association's involvement will enable China to benefit from the best international experience, technical knowledge and practices. This is particularly relevant in the case of health promotion to control chronic and non-communicable diseases, STDs and HIV, in which China's experience is limited. E. Bank Group Experience and Lessons Learned 1.16 Lessons learned from previous Bank Group projects in China and elsewhere have benefited the design of this project. In addition, non-Bank experience in the fields of imnmunization, communication, health promotion and management of chronic diseases, HIV and AIDS has been considered. Close attention has likewise been given to experience of the Government and other agencies in relevant fields in China. Lessons learned from Bank Group financed health projects implemented worldwide and summarized in OED reports are detailed in ANNEX 12. 1.17 Lessons from Bank Group Experience in China. The Bank Group has supported seven health projects in China since the early 1980s. The first two projects -- the Rural Health and Medical Education Project (Cr. 1472-CHA) and the Rural Health and Preventive Medicine Project (Cr. 1713-CHA/Ln. 2723-CHA) -- have been completed except for the vaccine production component of the second project. Four health projects are currently being implemented. The Integrated Regional Health Development Project (Cr. 2009-CHA) focuses on improved planning of health services, and includes a disease prevention component. The Infectious and Endemic Disease Control Project (Cr. 2317-CHA) supports national programs for control of tuberculosis and schistosomiasis. The Rural Health Workers Development Project (Cr. 2539-CHA) focuses on improved planning and training of the rural health work-force. The Comprehensive Maternal and Child Health (MCH)
 - 6 - Project (Cr. 2655-CHA) will improve basic MCH services, training and management in eight of the poorest provinces of China. Finally, the Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Project (Cr. 2756- CHA; Ln. 3914-CHA), approved in June 1995, would help the Government's goal to eliminate iodine deficiency disorders in China by the year 2000. Two additional projects, the Medium-sized Cities Development Project (Cr. 2201-CHA; Ln. 3286-CHA) and the Second Rural Water Supply Project (Cr. 2336-CHA), also include health components. Financing preventive health care, including childhood immunization, is a main issue being addressed under the ongoing Health Care Finance Study. 1.18 The main lessons from earlier health projects in China include the need to ensure: well- organized and adequately staffed project management offices at all levels; advance planning to ensure adequate counterpart financing; and flexible project design that can respond to changing circumstances, which is especially important in China's rapidly transforming economy. The project design has fully taken these lessons into account. Almost all provinces and cities have already established project management offices and have designated key staff. The central Ministry of Finance (MOF) has already obtained full commitment from all project provinces and cities for budgetary provisions for necessary counterpart funding. Written commitments to these and other critical steps have been required as conditions of participation by the provinces and cities in the proposed project. 1.19 Lessons from Experience in Disease Prevention. There is a large storehouse of experience, both inside and outside China, on the design and implementation of immunization programs. The major lessons considered in this project include: that strong national commitment and target-setting can result in a high level of achievement, but there may be a risk of over-reporting; that coverage of certain sections of the population (especially the poorest) can be inadequate in the absence of special targeting; and that it is important to include an effective communication strategy. 1.20 The proposed project would not only strengthen China's immunization surveillance system, but it would also include three special cluster surveys -- at the start, at the middle and at the end of the project. Special steps would be made to ensure that the poorest and the migrating ("floating") families would be adequately covered (para. 5.7). To respond to the need for improved communications for the immunization program, the project would include a separate information, education and communication (IEC) sub-component that would build on the experiences of similar projects in the Philippines, Bangladesh and Ecuador. This project component's communication strategy, aimed at increasing immunization coverage and child survival, would include: (a) identifying the target audience; (b) understanding the factors in low compliance; (c) choosing desired and appropriate media mix; and (d) selecting the means to change behavior. 1.21 As China's experience in health promotion for the prevention of chronic diseases, STDs and HIV is limited, the project draws heavily from the Bank's and other international agencies' worldwide experience. On chronic diseases, the project design has benefited from the international findings of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the successful Finnish and Australian experience. The behavioral risk factor assessment, the IEC programs and on-site intervention programs will all benefit from such experience. In HIV/AIDS prevention, Bank experience in Brazil, Burkina Faso, India, Uganda, Zaire and Zimbabwe has particularly guided the development of the following project components: (a) surveillance and evaluation; (b) institutional development for inter-sectoral coordination and improved program management and laboratories' staff
 - 7 - skills; and (c) improved management of STDs. Finally, based on the lessons learned, attempts were made to keep the project design simple and flexible.

Project Development Project Design 2.1 The proposed project was designed to meet two distinct disease prevention objectives: (a) to improve immunization coverage to reduce vaccine-preventable infectious diseases in poor areas of China, making a significant contribution toward achieving the Government's goal of alleviating the impact of poverty; and (b) to enhance China's capacity to plan and implement programs to control the rising prevalence of NCDs, STDs/HIV and injury. The first objective would be addressed through the Immunization Component, which would improve the access, coverage and quality of immunization throughout ten of China's poorest provinces. The program would be based on well- established domestic and world-wide experience and practices. This component involves about 85 percent of the project cost. The second objective would be addressed through an innovative Health Promotion Component, which would be implemented in seven cities and, to a more limited extent, in Yunnan Province. These areas' diverse characteristics are expected to lead to wider replication of this component elsewhere. Because of its innovative nature, the design of this component has benefitted from a considerable amount of international technical assistance, which is expected to continue well into the implementation phase. Some of the interventions under the Health Promotion Component would be designed and developed only after the start of project implementation and in light of findings of the behavioral risk factor surveys (para. 4.31) and the initial experience under the project. This component accounts for less than 15 percent of the project cost. Finally, a National- level Component would be included, with an allocation of about two percent of the project cost, to coordinate the implementation of both components, to provide policy guidance and technical assistance to the cities and the provinces, and to eventually disseminate the lessons learned under the project. Project Preparation Process 2.2 The preparation of this project was entirely managed and implemented by Chinese officials at various levels. During the Identification Mission, the Ministry of Health (MOH) officials and Bank Group staff identified a long list of activities which might fit the project objectives. MOH also identified two provinces (for the Immunization Component) and two cities (for the Health Promotion Component) to start the project preparation process. Following field visits and detailed discussions between Bank Group staff and Chinese officials, a detailed project preparation plan (PPP) was agreed upon, specifying the roles and responsibilities of various parties, technical assistance requirements and schedule. 2.3 During the Preparation Assistance Mission, project proposals prepared by two sample provinces, four counties and two cities were reviewed, further joint field visits were made, and the PPP was revised. During the Pre-appraisal Mission, project proposals from all ten candidate provinces and seven candidate cities were reviewed, plans and progress of special studies and surveys were reexamined, and additional field visits were made. The PPP was further revised and converted into an outline of the project implementation plan (PIP). The MOH completed a comprehensive PIP for the appraisal, based upon the project proposals prepared by each of the project provinces and
 cities. After necessary revisions, the PIP became the most comprehensive of the project documents and a basis for project implementation. Stakeholder Participation 2.4 Stakeholder involvement in the preparation process has been very high. First, each of the ten candidate provinces prepared proposals for the Immunization Component, based upon county proposals and other inputs from the lower levels. Similarly, each of the seven cities and Yunnan Province prepared its plans under the Health Promotion Component. Most of the provinces and cities were visited by joint teams from MOH and the Bank for discussions. Finally, three comprehensive project preparation and review workshops were carried out for each of the two main components (immunization and health promotion). These workshops provided productive forums and opportunities for: (a) thorough examination of the findings and recommendations of the joint MOH- IDA missions; (b) exchange of views among the local officials and between the Chinese and international experts; and (c) provision of feedback to the MOH-IDA teams to improve the project design. In addition to the workshops held in connection with the IDA mission, MOH also held a number of workshops with domestic experts and a few with external specialists. Exposure to International Experience 2.5 A major highlight of the preparation process was the interaction between the Chinese experts and top-level international experts in the relevant fields. For the preparation of the Immunization Component, technical assistance was provided by experts from WHO, CDC and others. The design of the Health Promotion Component benefitted from technical collaboration of experts from prominent sources, including WHO, CDC, the Finnish National Public Health Institute and Australian health agencies. Considerable technical assistance is also anticipated for this component during project implementation. B. Project Areas Selection Criteria 2.6 Poverty alleviation by improving the health status of the poorest population of China was the main criteria of selecting the project provinces under the Immunization Component, which involves about 85 percent of the project costs. To select the provinces under this component, all Chinese provinces were ranked on the basis of a set of indicators including per-capita income, percentage of population under the poverty line and disease incidence, and a list of the 15 most disadvantaged provinces was determined. The list was further reduced by excluding those with very small population size, a low level of interest, and recent experience with other Bank-assisted health projects in China. Finally, the ten provinces ranked as the most disadvantaged under these criteria were selected for the project. For the selection of Health Promotion Component cities, the main emphasis was on: (a) diversity (in size and location) to allow wider replication; (b) health risk factors; and (c) capacity and commitment to implement the project.

 - 11 - 3. THE PROJECT A. Project Objectives 3.1 The project has two objectives: (a) Prevent and control vaccine-preventable diseases to reduce morbidity, disability and mortality, especially in the poorest provinces of China. This would be carried out by improving the immunization services and by introducing policy measures to improve vaccine quality and to ensure access of all population groups, and to add new vaccines to the Expanded Program on Immunization; and (b) Improve the capacity of the health sector to design and implement health promotion programs to prevent and control the rising prevalence of NCDs, STDs/HIV and injury. This would be accomplished through policy and institutional improvements and by implementing pilot programs, including surveillance, staff training, health education and other health promotion interventions, at selected locations. B. Project Description 3.2 The project comprises three main components: (a) immunization; (b) health promotion; and (c) the national-level programs. Detailed descriptions of these components can be found in ANNEXES 1. 2 and 3. A summary description is given below. Immunization 3.3 The Immunization Component would be implemented in ten of the poorest provinces of the country - Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Hebei, Henan, Hubei, Shaanxi, Shanxi, Xinjiang and Yunnan. The component consists of four sub-components: (a) cold chain improvement; (b) health workers' training; (c) management and surveillance; and (d) information, education and communication. 3.4 A majority of cold chain equipment for storage and transport of vaccines at all levels is now either damaged or approaching the end of its expected service life. Any breakdown in the cold chain can seriously damage vaccine potency. To ensure the sustainability of the immunization program, a 20-year needs assessment has been prepared for new installation and regular replacement of equipment. Benefits 5.1 Through the Immunization Component (85 percent of the total project base cost), the project would most directly benefit about six million infants born each year in ten of China's poorest provinces by more effectively protecting them against mortality and morbidity caused by measles, polio, pertussis, diphtheria and tuberculosis. The project will also make tetanus toxoid and hepatitis B vaccines more accessible to families, reduce the risk of death due to neonatal tetanus, and protect the population from the long-term consequences of hepatitis B infection. The project will support 36 percent of nationally identified tetanus toxoid counties in its National Plan of Action for Elimination of Neonatal Tetanus. The main beneficiaries would be those who currently have the least access to satisfactory quality immunization services. The project will not only help China narrow the health gaps between the poor and rich and between urban and rural populations, it will also help significantly to reverse the declines in resource allocations to preventive health care that have resulted in reduced coverage and quality of immunization in China. Furthermore, by reversing the declining trend in resource allocation for preventive health, it will build a strong foundation for the preventive health care system. 5.2 The project also includes specific interventions designed to improve planning and management capacity of the national, provincial, and county governments to prepare and implement immunization programs, hence reducing unnecessary wastage of vaccines. Furthermore, the project addresses the need for periodic in-service training, operational costs of preventive programs and program management and, at least in part, alleviation of the problem of inability to pay for essential disease prevention services, all of which are expected to demonstrate to the government the value of maintaining such recurrent costs. 5.3 Economic Benefits. The project will reduce the burden of communicable diseases by about 60 percent. The benefits of the project are quantified as disability adjusted life years saved (DALY) or healthy years of life gained from the immunization program. Based on epidemiological data, vaccine efficiency, and the target population, the results indicate that immunization would save about 4.8 million DALY annually in the ten project provinces, and approximately $622 million in lost income and treatment costs; reflecting a significant return on the investment. See ANNEX 10 for details. 5.4 Cost-Effectiveness. The cost-effectiveness of the immunization program is calculated against program alternatives. Comparing estimates of DALY saved per RMB from vaccines with alternative programs of outpatient care demonstrate clearly that immunization programs are much more cost-effective. For instance, for a fixed amount of resources, vaccination against measles and DPT would save 13 and 7 times more healthy life years, respectively, than would outpatient treatment. Thus, immunization services that have few acceptable private alternatives would have a particularly large payoff to the public (ANNEX 10).

 - 59 - ANNEX 4 REPLACEMENT AND LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF THE COLD CHAIN 1. Justification. During the 1980s, as part of its participation in the Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) and its commitment to the Universal Childhood Immunization goal for 1990, China with international assistance embarked on the establishment of a complete cold chain system extending from the vaccine factories to village level immunization posts. Most of the vehicles and equipment used in this cold chain were purchased and installed in the late 1980s. In the rush to expand capacity, inadequate provisions were made by the government at each level for the inevitable need to replace equipment as it wears out. Although some replacement purchases have been made and a limited amount of donations are still provided, the current levels are inadequate to prevent serious deterioration in the cold chain in the next few years, including breakdowns of the system in some areas. Assistance is needed while the government establishes a more sustainable long-term replacement program. In addition to replacement of the current cold chain, some expansion and changes in standards are needed, both to improve quality and to accommodate new vaccines, in particular the routine use of hepatitis B vaccine. 2. Standards. In order to calculate the requirements for cold chain replacement and expansion, both for the project period and in the future, a series of standards were established based on experience in China and international standards used by the World Health Organization. These are as follows: (a) The standard types and quantities of cold chain equipment needed at province, prefectural, county, township and village level depending on the size of the units and the organization of immunization services within them (See Table A4-1). Due to the need to improve sterile technique at the immunization point level, steam sterilizers, needles and syringes are included in the list even though they are not "cold chain" equipment per se. (b) The estimate unit costs for appropriate equipment of each type, and the proportion of the standard quantity for each type and level that will need to be provided during the next five years in order to restore and expand the cold chain. This proportion is based on a review of the current situation in China and the expected working life of each type of equipment. 3. Calculations. Based on the above standards, equipment replacement during the project was calculated. (a) First, provinces provided information on the number and characteristics of each level of their immunization services (province, prefecture, county, township and village). (b) Second, replacement quantities were calculated by multiplying the number and types of service units in each province by the equipment standards for that level and the replacement proportion under the project. Numbers of equipment were rounded up to the nearest integer.
 - 60 - ANNEX 4 (c) Third, costs of equipment replacement were estimated by multiplying equipment numbers by equipment unit costs (See Table A4-2 and ANNEX 6 for summary costs). 4. Sustainability. In order to avoid repeating the mistake of not planning for long-term replacement, the average life-expectancy of each type of equipment was estimated and overall replacement needs for each of three five year periods after the project were calculated, preparing the needs assessment for a total of 20-year plan for the cold chain. The costs of the three five year periods after the project will need to be borne entirely by the government. Although costs vary between periods, the overall cost can be estimated as equivalent to about 0.14 RMB per capita per year, including the costs of replacing sterilizers, needles and syringes. While not negligible, such an amount is well within the capacity of all project provinces. Each province was requested to establish a system for meeting these costs both in terms of counterpart funds during the project and full costs after the project. 5. During appraisal all provinces agreed with the long-term needs assessment for the cold chain replacement program. In some provinces measures to ensure financial support for the long-term have already been initiated, including increased government budget allocations, and designation of some of the funds collected from EPI contracts or rural taxes to support cold chain replacement. The project provinces have also proposed, but not yet adopted, additional measures including financing from rural cooperative medical insurance, pre-financing of future needs by establishing an equipment depreciation fund, charges on health care institutions that fail to provide EPI services, use of funds previously allocated to special polio national immunization days, solicitation of donations for major items, and a request that national finance department guidelines be established making cold chain replacement a standard line item in the health budget.

 - 72 - ANNEX 9 PROJECT PERFORMANCE MONITORING 1. Actions to Monitor Outcome Objectives. Tracking key monitoring indicators is necessary to measure the impact of the project inputs on the key development objectives. These indicators have been prepared and will be monitored throughout the project cycle. At the mid-term review, the need to fine-tune or restructure the project design will be based on the data received from these indicators. 2. As the reduction of morbidity and mortality is the ultimate goal of the immunization program, demonstration of a reduction in these two areas should provide final proof of success or failure. In the context of the Health Promotion Component, outcome will be measured by behavioral changes and environmental changes which will be conducive to eventual modification of risk factors. Many of the ultimate outcomes, e.g., disease prevention and reduced mortality, may not decrease in the project period, except perhaps injuries. Given the essential role program monitoring and evaluation play in determining the impact of a given intervention on development objectives, three sets of indicators will be used to monitor and evaluate progress during implementation of the Immunization and Health Promotion Components: input indicators, process/output indicators and outcome indicators. 1. Immunization Component A. Outcome Indicators 3. Outcome Indicators will track whether or not the development objectives of the project have been met. Criteria for selection of these outcome indicators for health status are: (a) that the indicator is known to be sensitive to the intervention introduced under the project; and (b) that data will be readily available through routine collection on a county and provincial basis without special surveys. Based on these criteria, outcome indicators selected include: (a) infant mortality rate; (b) under 5 mortality rate; and (c) disease incidence trends for poliomyelitis, measles and neonatal tetanus. 4. Process indicators will enable the program managers and the Association to assess desirable improvement in management and quality of immunization programs, e.g., increase in immunization coverage, and improvements in management and quality of vaccine handling and distribution. Eight process indicators will be tracked annually. (a) coverage of EPI (4 vaccines) (through review of immunization records by county EPI supervisors annually, with estimations of coverage using both registered children and estimated births for each township); (b) coverage of measles vaccine, annually for province, prefecture, and counties for children under age 5; (c) number of counties reporting age and immunization status of all measles cases (annually); (d) coverage of hepatitis B vaccine, urban and rural; (e) coverage of tetanus toxoid for women of childbearing age and pregnant women;
 - 73- ANNEX 9 (f) supervision rates from county to township (minimum 2x per year per township), township to village (2x per year per village); (g) proportion of village doctors implementing single needle and single syringe policy; and (h) the number of immunization sessions held annually. 5. Evaluation of Coverage. In addition to the routine reports, population based assessment of vaccine coverage (modified WHO cluster survey) will be carried out at the beginning, middle and the end of the project to establish baseline coverage and validate routine reports. The cluster survey provides an estimate of coverage by examining seven children within the target age-group in each of 30 randomly selected clusters. Provided that these 210 children are randomly selected, the evaluation can, with 95 percent confidence, predict the antigen coverage being achieved within plus or minus 10 percent limits. The design of the cluster survey will be finalized by CAPM in a manner satisfactory to the Association. B. Performance Indicators 6. Input indicators will track planned investment in terms of time (staff-weeks and staff-months) in training programs by level of health workers and procurement of goods (cold chain equipment and other training and equipment -- disbursement rate). These indicators will be represented in standard input tables of each major sub-component of the project. 7. Output indicators will track items such as: (a) number of training modules that have been revised and completed by a given date during the project cycle; (b) equipment or vehicles that have been procured; (c) the number of village, township and county health workers that have been trained; and (d) the number of prefectures, counties, and townships equipped with cold chain equipment. These indicators will be tracked in output tables for each component of the project. II. Health Promotion Component A. Outcome and Environment Indicators 8. Outcome indicators can be used to monitor progress toward meeting development objectives of the project. In the context of health promotion, these are: behavioral changes, knowledge, and risk factor prevalence (smoking rates in the population by age, percentage of doctors that are non- smokers), which can be measured through the BRFSS. 9. Environment indicators measure outcomes in changes in policy, e.g., market shares of media sports, implementation of no smoking in public areas and number of non-smoking signs in schools, work-site and hospitals. These environmental indicators will be tracked during the project. 10. Output indicators will track items such as: (a) the number of reports, policies implemented, study tours and overseas training completed by a given date during the project cycle; (b) the number of students trained; number of private doctors trained with standard STD management; number of clinics providing condoms with STD management; (c) the equipment or vehicles that have been procured; (d) response rate of questionnaires and timely report rate under the behavioral risk factor surveillance; (e) number of persons covered under the intervention by setting; and (f) number of mass
 - 74 - ANNEX 9 media programs and number of health columns in newspapers under the intervention sub-component. These indicators will be tracked in standard output tables for each major sub-component of the project. B. Performance Indicators 11 Input indicators are used to monitor progress toward meeting the implementation objectives of the project. Input indicators will track planned investment in terms of contracting technical assistance (staff weeks) and training activities and procurement of goods (disbursement). 12. Input/Output Tables have been prepared for each sub-component of the project. These tables will be finalized during the first supervision mission and will be used to monitor the progress in project implementation. As part of project supervision undertaken by the Association, the above input and output indicators will be monitored twice a year. Environment indicators will be monitored three times during the project. In addition, a special coverage survey will be carried out at the beginning, middle and the end of the project to establish a baseline and to validate routine reports.
 - 75 - ANNEX 10 ECONOMIC ANALYSIS I. Introduction 1. This section shows how epidemiological and demographic data are used to calculate the benefits of the project as healthy years of life gained (HYL) or disability adjusted life years saved (DALY) from immunization program. It then examines cost-effectiveness of the programn compared with program alternatives in Section II, and assesses the fiscal impact of the project in Section III. Section IV conducts a sensitivity analysis of different vaccine parameters. The penultimate section succinctly describes the project's impact on poverty alleviation. 2. Economic Benefits. The results show that the Immunization Component would save about 4.8 million DALY annually in the ten project provinces, reflecting about 60 percent reduction in the burden of communicable diseases. This is based on such epidemiological data as the average age at onset, case fatality rates, the duration of disability, and the incidence of diseases. The total disease burden -- the sum of all DALY lost by the population in the ten project provinces -- is computed first (Table 1)1'. It is clear that non-communicable diseases (NCDs) account for the bulk of the disease burden -- 68 percent of total DALY lost -- followed by communicable diseases (22 percent) and injuries (10 percent). Of the total DALY lost, malignant neoplasm and cardiovascular diseases steal more than a half of healthy life years in these provinces (Table 2). Having estimated the loss in DALY, the next step is to compute the gains in DALY that would be possible under the immunization program. Based on the number of immunizations, their efficiency and the target population, DALY saved per vaccination is calculated (Table 3). Multiplying column (2) by column (5) generates DALY saved annually per immunization (column 6). The sum yields savings of about 4.86 million DALY per year. 3. Furthermore, the Immunization Component would save approximately $622 million in lost income and treatment costs, reflecting a significant return on project investment. Monetary values of benefits -- the value of life saved from reduced illness time and deaths avoided, reduced expenditure on treatment, and value of time spent in home care -- are estimated with data from several household surveys. In this respect, a year of life saved is valued at annual per capita national income, and treatment costs are adjusted for reduced use and coverage. 4. It is worth pointing out that in some cases the data on the duration of disability and proportion of permanent disability were not available from the project provinces. In such cases the national social weights were assumed in the DALY calculations. Alternatively, social weights by age from other countries with similar age patterns of mortality can be used, but they vary more widely across cultures and social context than within a country. Indeed, DALY estimates vary significantly when global weights are used. 1' For details on methodology to calculate DALY, see C.J.L. Murray and A.D. Lopez, "The Global Burden of Disease," World Development Report, 1993; Background Paper.
 - 76 - ANNEX 10 II. Cost-Effectiveness and Program Alternatives 5. The cost-effectiveness of the immunization program is calculated against program alternatives --that is the cost and effect of outpatient care in the absence of the project (Table 4). Estimates of DALY saved per RMB from vaccines are compared with alternative programs of outpatient treatment. Data on costs per visit and average annual coverage of outpatient care are from several surveys. Multiplying incidence with coverage and cost per visit yields total cost. Dividing DALY saved per immunization from Table 3 by total cost gives DALY saved per RMB. The results demonstrate clearly that immunization programs are much more cost-effective. For instance, for a fixed amount of resources, vaccination against measles and DPT would save 13 and 7 times more healthy life years, respectively, than would outpatient treatment. Thus, immunization services that have few acceptable private alternatives would have a particularly large payoff to the public. III. Fiscal Impact (Project Sustainability) 6. Whether the project has a positive fiscal impact overall depends largely on whether levels of recurrent expenditures needed to operate new facilities after the project ceases are sufficient. The additional recurrent costs requirements created by new investments are estimated and then examined in relation to projected recurrent expenditure constraints in government health budgets. At the end of the project, the total cost is $26.27 million, and the value of investment remaining at the end of project is $15.51 million. Total cost less value of investment at the end of project is $10.76 million. From these estimates, for operating cost in sixth year and thereafter, the government would need $4.93 million annually (RMB 40.9 million at a 1995 exchange rate). This figure represents less than one percent of projected total recurrent government health budget of RMB 4.5 billion in 2000. Since cost sharing and other measures to reduce recurrent costs are now being introduced in many communities of the ten project provinces, the incremental recurrent cost will be well within sustainable limits. IV. Sensitivity Analysis 7. Sensitivity of the project is analyzed with respect to changes in such parameters as the cost of vaccines, the effectiveness of vaccines, and the population coverage of immunizations. The sensitivity is tested with an increase of cost of vaccines from 10 to 25 percent; DALY saved per RMB did not make any significant difference in Table 5. But the project is more sensitive to changes in the effectiveness of vaccines. Thus, the successful implementation of the immunization program depends largely on how the program is managed including the condition of cold chain, and the maximum effectiveness depends on whether immunization is carried out according to a full schedule, e.g., second and third doses for DPT. In turn, effectiveness of vaccines is sensitive to the changes in the vaccination rate. The project is also sensitive to changes in coverage of immunizations for tuberculosis and hepatitis B. For instance, if the population coverage for BCG falls below 20 percent, DALY saved per immunization falls significantly and is not a cost-effective option when compared with outpatient care. Three important conclusions emerge from the sensitivity analysis. First, the costs of vaccines are very low, and even significant cost increases will not reduce the marked gains in healthy life years. Second, the management and surveillance of the cold chain are sensitive to the design of immunization programs. Finally, hepatitis B and BCG vaccines should be administered more effectively.
 - 77 - ANNEX 10 V. Poverty Alleviation 8. Under the project the majority of beneficiaries (66 percent) belong to poor families in 392 poverty counties. Components to promote immunization and health would have both direct and indirect effects on their welfare. Because these components would enhance the access of poor children and mothers to EPI, thus preventing future illnesses directly, the components would also help indirectly reduce the loss of income among working mothers due to illness, thus eventually augmenting their productivity and income earning opportunities.

 - 83 - ANNEX 12 QUESTIONNAIRE CONCERNING REVIEW OF OED REPORTS INVESTMENT PROJECTS 1. How many OED reports have been completed on projects in the same sector as the proposed project for: (a) the same country: I; (b) the same region: 18 ; and (c) for all countries worldwide: 64 2. What are the main technical lessons learned from the these reports? From the OED reports and relevant IDA projects in the same sector in China, the lessons leamed are as follows: (a) Project design and implementation arrangements should be flexible enough to adapt to changing circumstances. (b) Vaccines should be maintained in cold chain equipment at the correct temperatures from manufacturer to user. Adequate equipment maintenance is also a key factor for sustaining project impact and project design, and measures should be included to encourage the continuation of maintenance beyond the project period. (c) Clear and realistic project monitoring and evaluation guidelines and indicators should be defined prior to effectiveness, which will allow the Government and the Bank to measure which interventions are being effectively implemented, and which interventions require modifications to better achieve the desired results. (d) Sensitivity to local culture is emphasized, especially in projects which address themselves to the eradication of disease, and the project design should take into account the optimum means by which interventions may produce the desired result. (e) Well-organized and staffed project management offices should be established at all operational levels, which can significantly contribute to smooth implementation of the project. (f) Certain sections of the population (especially the poorest) can be undercovered in the absence of special targeting. (g) Regarding implementation of the AIDS/STDs sub-component, while Bank Group projects are relatively new and formal evaluations have not been undertaken, several early lessons emerge from these experiences: (1) collaboration among active donors (especially WHO) is very important; (2) HIV and STDs should be addressed together, as STDs are both a risk factor and a proxy for potential HIV infection; (3) social marketing of condoms brings significant benefits; and (4) use NGOs and the private sector in implementation, particularly to reach high risk groups, as they are better equipped than most governments to reach many communities.
 - 84 - ANNEX 12 3. What are the main policy and institutional design lessons learned from these reports? From the OED reports and relevant Bank Group projects in the same sector in China, the lessons learned are as follows: (a) Even when a project is located in permanent institutions, such as MOH, sustainability hinges on the government's commitment to support the new activities initiated by the project. (b) Advance planning is decisive to ensure adequate counterpart financing. 4. How has the proposed project design benefited from the above review of lessons learned? (a) The project contains a mid-term review, which requires revisiting all aspects of project design to ensure their continued relevance. (2a) (b) Cold chain management training is programmed under the project to help ensure correct vaccine temperature control. The project's design and the Government's 20-year plan for new installation and replacement of cold chain equipment contain specific provisions for equipment operation and maintenance, in the latter case beyond the life of the project. (2b) (c) The project's nature demands a strong and effective monitoring system. Therefore, comprehensive, yet practical, performance monitoring and evaluation systems have been specifically designed for both the Immunization and Health Promotion Components, which will be carefully reviewed throughout the project period. (2c) (d) The goal of tailoring and maximizing public acceptance of project messages will be achieved through the information, education and communication (IEC) sub-component. (2d, 2h) (e) Almost all project provinces and cities have established project management offices and designated key staff. (2e) (f) The project design includes special steps and targeting measures to ensure that the poorest and migrating ("floating") families would be adequately covered. (2f) (g) Regarding the AIDS/STDs sub-component: (1) WHO, joined by additional international expertise, has been very instrumental in project design; (2) special care was taken to ensure that STD-related problems are addressed with a view to AIDS/HIV issues, and interventions will help improve the management of STDs; (3) while condoms' distribution is not part of the project, the issue of social marketing will be addressed through the IEC strategy; and (4) the role of NGOs in China is relatively limited, but to the extent available, the project intends to involve NGOs in health promotion activities. doc.abstracts: The Disease Prevention Project has two objectives: 1) prevent and control vaccine-preventable diseases to reduce morbidity, disability and mortality, especially in the poorest provinces of China. This will be carried out by improving the immunization services and by introducing policy measures to improve vaccine quality and to ensure access of all population groups, and to add new vaccines to the Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI); and 2) improve the capacity of the health sector to design and implement health promotion programs to prevent and control the rising prevalence of non-communicable diseases (NCDs), sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)/human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and injury. This will be accomplished through policy and institutional improvements and by implementing pilot programs, including surveillance, staff training, health education and other health promotion interventions, at selected locations. The project comprises three main components: 1) immunization, which consists of four sub-components: (a) cold chain improvement; (b) health workers' training; (c) management and surveillance; and (d) information, education and communication; 2) health promotion, which will comprise the following sub-components: (a) institutional development and policy reform; (b) human resources development; (c) surveillance, especially behavioral risk factor surveillance; and (d) community-based interventions; and 3) the national-level programs.
